docs.lead_paragraph: Urging older people to have stress tests before they begin exercise programs, a common medical practice, is not only unfounded but may even discourage people from getting the physical activity they need, a new study reports. The vast majority of older people do not need the test, in which heart function is measured as a patient uses a treadmill, the researchers wrote in a recent issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association. Instead, they said, the patients should simply have complete physical examinations.

headline.main: Bypassing Stress Test on Way to Fitness

docs.abstract: New study finds urging older people to have stress tests before they begin exercise programs, common medical practice, is not only unfounded but may even discourage people from getting needed physical activity; holds most people do not need study of heart function, but should have complete physical exams; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Urging older people to have stress tests before they begin exercise programs, a common medical practice, is not only unfounded but may even discourage people from getting the physical activity they need, a new study reports.    The vast majority of...

docs.lead_paragraph: In her 1961 poem ''Grace,'' Maxine Kumin described hens pecking on gravel and the invincible armor one might gain by similarly ingesting small stones. ''I find it good to line my gut,'' she wrote, ''with tidy octagons of grit.'' Nearly four decades later, as she lay immobilized in the hospital with a nearly fatal spinal cord injury, Ms. Kumin's kernels of redemption were the words she managed to connect to her thoughts and ultimately commit to paper, at first dictating them when her own hands were incapable of typing. Although ''Grace'' didn't specifically come to mind as she kept her journal, Ms. Kumin said in a telephone interview, she has no doubt that writing (and her daughter Judith, who helped her to write) was her salvation.

headline.main: Two Fine Minds, Tested by Failing Bodies

docs.abstract: Leslie Berger article on books by Maxine Kumin and Christopher Reeve on how they dealt with spinal cord injuries; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A common strain of bacteria, already found to have a possible association with heart attacks, may also play a role in strokes, a new study has found. People infected with the bacterium, Chlamydia pneumomiae, appear four and a half times as likely to suffer a first is chemic stroke than uninfected people. The findings are reported in the July issue of the journal Stroke. Dr. Mitchell S. V. Elkind of Columbia University based the findings on a study of 89 stroke patients.

headline.main: Infection Appears to Pave Way for Stroke

docs.abstract: New study finds people infected with Chlamydia pneumomiae bacterium seem four and a half times more likely to suffer first ischemic stroke than uninfected people; finds those with signs of recent infection are most at risk, but that people infected in past several years are also at higher risk (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Alzheimer's disease, which robs people of their most basic neurological functions, may give subtle clues to its approach years before clear symptoms emerge. A recent study in The Archives of Neurology suggests that cognitive tests may allow doctors to know if a patient is developing the disease. While there is no treatment for Alzheimer's now, the technique could be useful as drugs become available.

headline.main: Experts Find Early Clues of Alzheimer's

docs.abstract: Study by Dr Merrill F Elias finds cognitive tests may allow doctors to know if patient is developing Alzheimer's disease years before clear symptoms emerge (M)
docs.snippet: Alzheimer's disease, which robs people of their most basic neurological functions, may give subtle clues to its approach years before clear symptoms emerge.    A recent study in The Archives of Neurology suggests that cognitive tests may allow...

docs.lead_paragraph: An emaciated boy named Michael sits in a hospital bed, intently playing a video game. Only 15, he looks like a wizened old man: the color of his skin gray, his hair falling out and the his arm and leg muscles all but melted away. He was referred for a possible diagnosis of anorexia nervosa. Michael has a much simpler explanation: ''Really, doc, I'm fine. I just don't want to eat anything that will corrode my arteries and give me a heart attack.''
docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel column says that while teenage girls in search of perfect body still make up majority of cases of anorexia nervosa, disorder is being reported across wide socioeconomic range; cites case of boy who died from self-starvation brought on by fear of effects of fats and cholesterol (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Recently, an article in a newspaper stated that ''at least 60 million people visit Internet health sites each year.'' This is not entirely accurate. I visit Internet health sites 60 million times each year. Until the development of the Internet, I kept my unhealthy interest in check by limiting my medical library to a few essential texts. That's the same principle that keeps me from bringing a deluxe Whitman's sampler box into my house: I would eat it all in one sitting. But now, it is as if my computer were spewing mocha cremes at me.

headline.main: Hyperlinks for Hypochondriacs: Old Malady in a New World

docs.abstract: Emily Yoffe humorous article on how Internet health sites are spurring her hypochondria; cites test for hypochondria she found on Internet; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Is the perfect golf swing, that elusive marriage of grace and strength that separates the duffer from the pro, about to yield its secrets to science? Unlikely, but researchers at the University of Chicago, using brain-imaging equipment, are studying how professional golfers prepare to swing, in the hope that it will help in physical rehabilitation.

headline.main: Exploring the Science of the Golf Swing

docs.abstract: University of Chicago researchers, using brain-imaging equipment, are studying how professional golfers prepare to swing in hope it will help in physical rehabilitation; seek understanding of nature of rapid body movement; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After seeing the movie ''Babe'' at age 9 and realizing the source of what was on her plate, Lauren Pierpoint of Boulder decided to stop eating meat. At age 6, Nathan Kessel of Boston was given a choice by his parents between a vegetarian diet and eating meat regularly; he has been a vegetarian for three years now. With a finicky toddler who would spit out any type of meat, Heidi Feldman of Norcross, Ga., decided ''almost overnight'' to put her entire family on a vegetarian diet. School lessons about endangered species combined with a visit to the zoo persuaded 7-year-old Laura Grzenda of Boulder to stop eating meat.

headline.main: Losing Meat, but Keeping a Child's Diet Balanced

docs.abstract: Vegetarian diets for children have become more accepted in recent years by some parents, doctors and nutritionists; pediatricians say they are seeing more children and adolescents choosing vegetarian diets; reasons for choice include picky eating, animal rights and environmental activism and desire to be 'hip'; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Are you confused about dietary fats? Well, you're not alone. Judging from the sometimes conflicting reports recently presented at a scientific conference, experts in the field seem to be having the devil's own time sorting out which fats and oils and how much of them are likely to be most beneficial to health and at the same time acceptable to consumers and food producers. The conference was organized by the American Heart Association, American Cancer Society and Oldways Preservation and Exchange Trust.

headline.main: In a Fat-Filled World, Some Sound Advice

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column offers advice on percentage and sources of fats in healthy diet; table (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people who are allergic to pollen presumably make it a point to avoid blooming fields of ragweed or goldenrod. But most people allergic to fish probably figure that to avoid an unpleasant reaction, they need only avoid eating anything that contains fish.

headline.main: Allergic to Fish? Avoid Air Around Them

docs.abstract: Researchers find people who are allergic to fish can get reaction from inhaling allergens wafting off fish skin and should avoid fish markets; photo (S)
